texts.definition: Alarms are abstract game elements that provide information about particular game state changes.
markups: <style="Definition">Alarms are abstract game elements that provide information about particular game state changes.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> are indicators that can show that important changes in the game state has occurred. This can be that fuel is nearly depleted in a race, a self-destruct has activated, that guards have detected the player's avatar or that an illegal activity has been observed. The activation of an <style="CurrentLink">Alarm</style> lets players know that a problem has occurred which likely needs to be dealt with while the de-activation lets them know that they are safer.

Some team-based first-person shooters, such as Return to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style>, include <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> to inform the players about events that are relevant on a team level, e. g., that a particular goal has been completed or that a certain activity has been initiated by the other team.

The main design choices for <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> are how they are activated, what <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> they set off, and if they indicate <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> or if they can be turned off. <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> may have diegetic counterparts through <style="Link"><link="switches">Switches</link></style> but for gameplay <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> need only be intangible constructs or simply reactions in <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>.

Further, designers may choose either explicit <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style> to manipulate the <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> or to have the manipulation of the <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> as <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> for certain types of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. Using <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style> increases the complexity of the game by allowing such possibilities as deactivating the <style="CurrentLink">Alarm</style> when it should not be deactivated, <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style> by raising erroneous <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style>, and preventing the raising of <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> by destroying the means to activate them. All these actions increase the player's <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> but may make it more difficult to guarantee specific <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> to occur. Having <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> to raise <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> may avoid this problem but may break the <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.

The activation of the <style="CurrentLink">Alarm</style> can signify the failure of a <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style> goal but can also make the completion of it more difficult by imposing a <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style>. This <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style> is often a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Time%20Limit">Time Limit</link></style>, the introduction of new <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, or directing existing <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> to the area where the <style="CurrentLink">Alarm</style> was raised.

By their nature of trying to get attention to some problematic state, <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> can cause <style="Link"><link="time-pressure">Time Pressure</link></style> as they often imply a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Time%20Limit">Time Limit</link></style>. An alternative to this is to let the de-activation of an <style="CurrentLink">Alarm</style> be a goal.
Of course, the pattern can most easily be deigetically be presented in a game as an alarm is some form or other.

<style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> are ways to pass information about activities and states within a game, and as such provide <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style>. When activated by players, an <style="CurrentLink">Alarm</style> notifies the players that they have been detected, and this can explain changes in the behavior of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> or the introduction of new <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> within the <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> of the game. When activated by others, <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> can notify players of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> activities. In both cases, they make <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals easier. Raised <style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style> and change how players have to relate to <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>.
<style="CurrentLink">Alarms</style> can both help create a <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> and be restricted in how they work by this.
